Award.AwardTitle: Mechanically strained silicon nanowire optoelectronic devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: We propose novel silicon nanowire device concepts that show the potential to efficiently emit light of various wavelengths. The underlying device physics that makes efficient photon emission theoretically possible is the direct bandgap of the nanowires and the short radiative recombination life-times. The tuning of emitted wavelength by applying reversible mechanical strain on nanowires is investigated. The proposed research involves a close interplay between fabrication, modeling and theory to realize tunable light emission from silicon nanowires by using the silicon-on-insulator platform.

Intellectual merit: The intellectual merit of the proposed research lies in gaining fundamental knowledge of the role of strain in tuning the optoelectronic response of silicon nanowires. While challenging, the realization of the proposed devices will offer an unique dimension allowing for the incorporation of strain in nanowires to yield the much desired optoelectronic response on silicon platform. The proposed pathways to engineer the optoelectronic response is also of basic importance to silicon based photovoltaics.

Broad impact: The proposed research has potential to permeate the fields of communication, medicine, defense and energy. End applications include lidars, imaging of tissue, light sources and photovoltaics. The training of graduate and undergraduate students in using silicon technology for applications that are fertile growth areas in the semiconductor industry is an integral part of this work. The topics of electromechanical properties of nanowires and the use of the silicon-on-insulator platform to create nanodevices will be introduced in undergraduate and graduate level nanotechnology courses. Our outreach activities will focus on low income K-12 students and the training of women and minority undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project researched the role of strain and electron-photon interaction in silicon nanostructures. The research results can be broadly classified into (1) Characterization of Silicon Nanowires, (ii) Photon induced Negative Capacitance and Photodetection, and (iii) Mechanical Strain induced modulation of the optoelectronic properties of Silicon Nanowires. This basic research produced results that may in future have the potential to impact the building of lasers and light emitting devices that utilize mechanical strain to control light emission.  The application of mechanical strain can induce the phenomenon of population inversion which is essential for lasing, and also control the color of the wavelength of light emitted.  Specifically, we demonstrate that the spontaneous emission time in Silicon Nanowires can be modulated by more than one order of magnitude by applying mechanical strain. The research performed also has potential to impact fields such as optical imaging by building cameras that can detect low light intensity and are based on silicon technology. The phenomenon of photon induced negative capacitance that was both experimentally observed and theoretically modeled was a byproduct of the basic research that was not originally expected. Here, we have found that by shining light on a capacitor with an ultrathin silicon body, it is possible to get a capacitance that is larger than the geometrical capacitance. The value of the capacitance can be tuned by the intensity of light, and this may find application in optoelectronics applications.

This project financially supported graduate students who performed the research during their doctoral thesis work via research assistantships. This project also helped high school and undergraduate students by defining research problems that they worked on. Course material on Silicon Nanowires which were used in both graduate and undergraduate courses were prepared and are freely available from the PI.  

This project supported the research leading to nine publications (6 published, three submitted) and one patent at the time of this report.
